questions.text: The X Ray of the skull as shown in the image given below is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hyperparathyroidism

 

Option A:

 

The given image is the X-ray of the skull is salt and pepper appearance which shows multiple tiny radiolucent lytic lesions due to resorption of the bone by PTH, seen in hyperparathyroidism. There is also a loss of definition between the skull's inner and outer tables.

 

Hyperparathyroidism, overactivity of the parathyroid glands leads to elevated levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which causes increased bone resorption. On skull X-rays, this can appear as a "salt and pepper" skull with numerous small, radiolucent areas where bone has been resorbed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Multiple Myeloma: Multiple myeloma is a hematological condition where malignant plasma cells proliferate in the bone marrow. It can lead to "punched out" lytic bone lesions on X-rays due to localized areas of bone resorption, but these tend to be larger than those seen in hyperparathyroidism and are often associated with other systemic symptoms.

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism: While hyperthyroidism can lead to osteoporosis, it is not typically characterized by the "salt and pepper" appearance seen in hyperparathyroidism. The bone changes in hyperthyroidism are more diffuse and less likely to present as discrete lytic lesions on the skull X-ray.

 

Option D. Paget's Disease: Paget's disease of bone involves abnormal bone remodeling, leading to enlarged and deformed bones. Radiographically, it can present with thickened cortical bone and areas of osteolysis, but the appearance is generally more disorganized and expansive than the discrete lytic lesions seen in hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "salt and pepper" appearance on skull X-ray, characterized by multiple tiny radiolucent lytic lesions due to bone resorption by PTH, is indicative of hyperparathyroidism.

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 598

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with diffuse back pain. Upon examination, there is no limitation of motion in the sacroiliac joints, and the intervertebral disc spaces appear preserved. The cervical spine X-ray reveals flowing ossifications along the anterolateral aspects of the vertebral bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DISH

 

Option B:

 

The age more than 50 yrs. and diffuse flowing ossification with no joint fusion and normal iv-disc space favors a diagnosis of DISH.

 

DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis) DISH is characterized by calcification and ossification of the spinal ligaments, particularly the anterior longitudinal ligament. On X-ray, DISH presents as flowing ossifications along the anterolateral aspects of at least four contiguous vertebral bodies with preservation of the disc spaces, without significant facet joint ankylosis or sacroiliac joint involvement.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) primarily affects the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton, leading to the fusion of affected joints, known as ankylosis. The hallmark radiographic findings in AS are sacroiliitis and syndesmophytes, leading to a "bamboo spine" appearance. However, the intervertebral disc spaces are typically preserved until late in the disease.

 

Option C. Klippel-Feil Syndrome: Klippel-Feil syndrome is a congenital condition characterized by the fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae. It may present with a short neck, limited neck movement, and low hairline. Radiographs would show fused cervical vertebrae, but not the flowing ossifications typical of DISH.

 

Option D. Sprengel Deformity: Sprengel deformity is a congenital condition in which the scapula is abnormally high due to its failure to descend during development. It's not related to spinal pathology and wouldn't show the characteristic findings of DISH on spinal imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray findings of flowing ossification along the anterior aspects of the thoracic spine with preserved intervertebral disc spaces in an elderly patient is indicative of DISH, which does not involve the sacroiliac joints.

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 616

questions.text: A 14-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of back pain and an abnormal curvature of the spine. Physical examination reveals a lateral curvature of the spine with a prominence of the left ribcage. The patient is otherwise healthy, with no other significant medical history. An X-ray of the spine is performed, which of the following angles would be measured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cobb angle

 

Option C:

 

Specific to scoliosis assessment, the Cobb angle quantifies the curvature's magnitude in the coronal plane. You draw perpendicular lines to the tilted endplates of the most tilted vertebrae above and below the curve, and the angle between these lines is the Cobb angle.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bohler angle: The Bohler angle, or tuber joint angle, is used in orthopedics to assess calcaneal fractures on lateral foot radiographs. It is formed by the intersection of two lines: one drawn from the highest point of the anterior process of the calcaneus to the highest point of the posterior articular surface and the other from the highest point of the posterior articular surface to the highest point of the posterior aspect of the calcaneus.

 

Option B. Gissane angle: Also known as the critical angle, it’s measured on lateral foot radiographs and used to assess calcaneal fractures, similar to the Bohler angle. It's formed by the downward and inward slopes of the calcaneus' superior surfaces.

 

Option D. Kite angle: This is used in pediatric orthopedics to assess the angular relationship between the talus and the first metatarsal in feet with flatfoot deformity on AP radiographs. It evaluates the congruence of the talonavicular joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cobb angle is the correct parameter for quantifying the degree of scoliotic curves on spine radiographs, aiding in the diagnosis and management of scoliosis.

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 660

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of backache. On examination, her eyes and pinna revealed blackish discoloration. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Alkaptonuria  

 

Option C:

 

Intervertebral disc calcification is seen in the image suggestive of alkaptonuria.

 

Deficiency: Homogentisic oxidase

 

Hyperpigmentation of ears and eyes suggestive of ochronosis is a clue. It is seen due to excessive build-up of homogentisic acid.

 

Alkaptonuria is a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisic acid oxidase, leading to an accumulation of homogentisic acid. This can result in ochronosis, the darkening of the connective tissues, including the sclera of the eye and ear cartilage. The spine radiograph can show intervertebral disc calcification, which is consistent with alkaptonuria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis): DISH is characterized by calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and entheses, the bony attachments of tendons and ligaments. It commonly affects the thoracic spine and is associated with diabetes and obesity. It does not typically cause discoloration in the eyes or pinna.

 

Option B. Fluorosis: Dental and skeletal fluorosis result from chronic exposure to high levels of fluoride and can lead to mottling of teeth and calcification of ligaments. While it can cause skeletal changes, the blackish discoloration of the eyes and pinna is not a feature of fluorosis.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Ankylosing spondylitis is an inflammatory disease that can cause fusion of the spine, leading to a characteristic bamboo spine appearance on X-ray. It does not, however, cause hyperpigmentation of the ears and eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of blackish discoloration of the eyes and pinna, along with the radiographic finding of intervertebral disc calcification, is indicative of alkaptonuria, a disorder of homogentisic acid metabolism leading to ochronosis and potential joint degeneration.

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 628

choices.text: Hypodense on CT
Anechoic on US
Hypo-intense on T1-MRI
Hypo-intense on T2-MRI

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with a slow-growing, painless mass on her upper back that has been present for several years. The mass is soft and mobile, with a doughy texture. Physical examination reveals a 5 cm subcutaneous mass that is well-circumscribed and non-tender. There is no erythema, warmth, or fluctuance. The patient is otherwise healthy, with no other significant medical history. The clinician makes a diagnosis of lipoma. Which of the following statements would be true about the lesion on imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypodense on CT

 

Option A:

 

Lipomas typically appear as hypodense (lower attenuation compared to surrounding tissue) on CT scans because they are composed of fat, which has less density than muscle or fluid. On Hounsfield units (HU), they generally measure between -50 and -150.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Anechoic on US: On ultrasound, lipomas are usually hyperechoic or have mixed echogenicity due to the presence of fat and fibrous tissue. Anechoic would imply the lesion is fluid-filled, which is not characteristic of lipomas.

 

Option C. Hypo-intense on T1-MRI: This is not true for lipomas; they are actually hyperintense on T1-weighted MRI images because fat has a high signal on T1.

 

Option D. Hypo-intense on T2-MRI:  Again, this is incorrect for lipomas. Lipomas are usually also hyperintense on T2-weighted MRI images because fat has a high signal on T2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

On CT imaging, a lipoma will present as a hypodense lesion due to its fat content, with negative HU values ranging between -50 and -150.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 554

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of a slow-growing mass on his thigh that has been present for several months. He reports that the mass is painless but has been increasing in size. Physical examination reveals a firm, non-tender mass measuring approximately 5 cm in diameter. The overlying skin is normal, with no signs of inflammation or discoloration. Investigation of choice for soft tissue sarcoma is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. MRI

 

Option B:

 

MRI is the modality of choice for assessing soft tissue sarcomas, as it is best able to locally stage a tumor. On a T1 MRI, these tumors are intermediate to low signal intensity, similar to adjacent muscle and on T2 MRI they are intermediate to high intensity tumor.

 

MRI Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is the preferred method for local staging of STS. It offers excellent contrast resolution, allowing for a detailed assessment of the tumor's relationship to adjacent structures. MRI is superior in evaluating the extent of the tumor, its relation to the neurovascular bundle, and any possible invasion into adjacent compartments.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CT: Computed Tomography (CT) can be useful for evaluating STS, especially to assess for metastatic disease. However, it is not the best modality for local staging due to its lower contrast resolution compared to MRI.

 

Option C. Ultrasound: While ultrasound can be used to differentiate cystic from solid masses and can be useful for guiding biopsies, it is not the investigation of choice for the assessment or staging of STS. Its utility is limited due to the operator-dependent nature and limited field of view.

 

Option D. X-ray: Plain radiographs (X-ray) have limited use in evaluating soft tissue masses, as they are best for assessing bones. Some STS may calcify and thus be visible on X-ray, but most will not be adequately visualized with this modality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the evaluation of soft tissue sarcomas, MRI is the imaging modality of choice due to its superior contrast resolution, which aids in detailed local staging and surgical planning.

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 556

choices.text: Aneurysmal bone cyst

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with pain on movement. X-ray of knee joint shows lytic lesion on the upper end of fibula as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Osteoclastoma

Option D:

 

Osteoclastoma are also known as Giant cell tumors typically appears as an EPIPHYSEAL, eccentric, well-defined, lytic lesion within the bone. The lesion may extend to the subchondral bone and may cause thinning or destruction of the cortex. There may also be evidence of cortical expansion or perforation, with a soft tissue mass visible on X-ray in some cases. The borders of the lesion may appear sclerotic, and there may be evidence of bone fragmentation or destruction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aneurysmal bone cysts are well defined geographic lucent lesions with a narrow zone of transition commonly found in the METAPHYSES.

 

Option B. Adamantinomas appear as a multilocular or slightly expansile osteolytic cortical lesion exclusively confined to the tibial diaphysis.

 

Option C. Chondroblastoma typically occurs in the epiphyses in the first two decades, and are well-defined lesions with ring and arc calcifications. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

An osteoclastoma, also known as a giant cell tumor, typically presents as an epiphyseal, eccentric, lytic lesion, which may extend to the subchondral bone and result in cortical thinning or destruction, characteristics that align with the radiographic findings in the presented case.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 570

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps with persistent low mood. Which of the following would be the best investigation for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sestamibi scan

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features of 40-year-old woman with bone pain and abdominal cramps along with persistent low mood is suggestive of hypercalcemia, which could be due to primary Hyperparathyroidism.

 

IOC for parathyroid adenoma: Tc99-Sestamibi scan

questions.text: A patient presented with neck pain and rigidity, which gets relieved after bathing in hot water and also after exercise. Cervical X-ray is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spondylolisthesis

 

Option A:

 

The lateral view of the X-ray shows fracture of pars interarticularis with a forward shift of the upper part of the spinal column over the stable vertebra below, known as spondylolisthesis. The gap in the pars interarticularis is best viewed in the oblique views, which can show the "beheaded scotty dog" sign or inverted "Napoleon hat" sign.

 

Spondylolisthesis This condition is characterized by the slippage of one vertebral body over the one below it. It can be observed on the lateral spinal X-ray as a forward shift, often with a visible fracture in the pars interarticularis, leading to what may be described as a "beheaded scotty dog" sign on oblique views.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Spondylosis:  Spondylosis refers to degenerative changes in the spine, including disc degeneration and osteophyte formation. While it can cause neck pain, the typical X-ray findings would be narrowed disc spaces, bony spurs, and possible facet joint hypertrophy, not a vertebral slip.

 

Option C. Compression Fracture: A compression fracture occurs when a vertebral body is compressed anteriorly, leading to a wedge-shaped vertebra on lateral X-ray. It typically results from osteoporosis or trauma, and the classic sign is a loss of height at the anterior aspect of the vertebral body.

 

Option D. Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis itself doesn't have a specific sign on an X-ray, but it predisposes to fractures, including compression fractures. It is usually diagnosed with a bone density scan (DEXA) and might show generalized low bone density on X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral cervical X-ray showing a forward shift of a vertebral body is indicative of spondylolisthesis, often associated with a pars interarticularis defect, which can be symptomatically relieved by heat and exercise due to muscle relaxation.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 816

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of acute onset pain and swelling in his right big toe. He reports that the pain is excruciating and is preventing him from walking. Physical examination reveals erythema and tenderness in the affected joint, with limited range of motion. X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gout

 

Option D:

 

Gout is an inflammatory arthritis caused by deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints. Acute attacks are extremely painful, often affecting the big toe, and X-ray findings may include soft tissue swelling and erosions with overhanging margins, often described as "rat-bite" erosions or Martel's sign, which seem consistent with the provided history and X-ray.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis is characterized by joint pain and stiffness, primarily in weight-bearing joints, due to cartilage breakdown. X-ray findings typically include joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes, and subchondral cysts. It usually does not present with the acute, severe inflammation seen in this case.

 

Option B. Rheumatoid Arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune condition that causes symmetrical joint inflammation. X-ray findings might show soft tissue swelling, osteopenia near the joint (periarticular osteopenia), uniform joint space narrowing, and marginal erosions, but it is more chronic and less localized than the presentation described.

 

Option C. Pseudo Gout: Pseudo gout, or calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), can cause acute monoarticular arthritis, but X-ray findings often show calcification in the cartilage (chondrocalcinosis), which is not described in the provided X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presentation of acute onset pain and swelling in the big toe, with X-ray findings of erosions and marked destruction of the metatarsal-phalangeal and interphalangeal joints, is typical of gout, often associated with "rat-bite" erosions or Martel's sign.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 624

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of joint pain and stiffness that has been ongoing for the past few months. She reports that the pain is worse in the morning and is relieved by movement throughout the day. She also reports swelling in her hands and feet, along with fatigue and weight loss. On physical examination, there is synovial swelling in multiple joints, particularly the small joints of the hands and feet. There is also tenderness and limited range of motion in these joints. Laboratory tests show an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) level. The X-ray of the hand is shown here. The patient shown below most likely has?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rheumatoid arthritis

 

Option B:

 

The characteristic changes seen in rheumatoid arthritis are erosions and joint space narrowing involving the MCP, intercarpal and PIP joints with characteristic sparing of the DIP as seen in the image.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteoarthritis would cause subchondral sclerosis and the formation of marginal osteophytes but not erosions. Osteoarthritis in the hand typically involves the distal interphalangeal joints.

 

Option C. Jaccoud’s arthropathy is associated with SLE wherein there are deformities typical in RA, but without any erosions.

 

Option D. Avascular necrosis of the hip is the most common site for osteonecrosis due to a combination of precarious blood supply and high loading when standing. It could lead to secondary osteoarthritis, but that is unlikely in the hand and would never involve this many joint. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray findings of joint space narrowing and erosions, particularly in the MCP and PIP joints with sparing of the DIP joints, in conjunction with the clinical presentation of morning stiffness, symmetrical joint pain, swelling, and systemic symptoms such as fatigue and weight loss, are characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 618

choices.text: Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 70yearold male presents with right wrist pain and the following radiograph. Which of the following is the most likely primary tumor if this is proven to be metastatic?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Renal cell carcinoma

 

Option A:

 

The radiograph shows a lytic lesion in the distal radius with associated pathologic fracturing. The most likely primary tumor is renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Bone metastases have been reported to occur in approximately 30% of patients with RCC. Metastatic lesions in RCC are typically expansile, lytic, and hypervascular.

 

Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC) Renal cell carcinoma is known for causing lytic bone metastases. RCC metastases are typically hypervascular and can lead to expansile lytic lesions, as seen on the provided radiograph. These lesions are often aggressive and can cause pathologic fractures, fitting the patient's clinical presentation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is a malignancy of the sympathetic nervous system that primarily affects children, usually under the age of 5. It can metastasize to the bone, presenting as lytic or mixed lytic-sclerotic lesions, but it would be extremely uncommon for it to be the source of metastasis in a 70-year-old.

 

Option C. Prostate Carcinoma:  Prostate cancer typically metastasizes to the bone in a blastic fashion, meaning that the lesions it creates are dense and sclerotic, not lytic. While patients with prostate cancer can present with bone pain, the radiographic appearance of their metastases usually differs from what is shown in this patient's radiograph.

 

Option D. Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma:  Papillary thyroid carcinoma primarily metastasizes to regional lymph nodes and, less commonly, to distant sites like the lungs and bones. When it does metastasize to bone, it can cause lytic lesions, but follicular thyroid carcinoma is more commonly associated with osseous metastases than papillary subtype.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of an expansile, lytic lesion in the distal radius with pathologic fracture in a 70-year-old patient is most consistent with metastatic renal cell carcinoma, which frequently manifests as hypervascular, aggressive lytic lesions in the bone.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 432

choices.text: Multiple osteochondromas: multiple hereditary exostoses
Multiple enchondromas: Maffucci syndrome
Multiple enchondromas: Ollier syndrome
Multiple FD: McCune Albright syndrome

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Multiple enchondromas: Maffucci syndrome

 

Option B:

 

Multiple enchondromas: Maffucci syndrome - Maffucci syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by multiple enchondromas—benign cartilaginous growths within the bones—and soft tissue hemangiomas. This diagnosis is supported by the radiographic findings which show multiple enchondromas in the hands along with phleboliths, indicative of hemangiomas.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multiple osteochondromas: multiple hereditary exostoses - Multiple hereditary exostoses are characterized by the presence of numerous osteochondromas, which are bony protrusions capped by cartilage. These typically arise on the external surface of bones, especially long bones, and are not usually seen within the short tubular bones of the hands as shown in the image.

 

Option C. Multiple enchondromas: Ollier syndrome - Ollier disease is a nonhereditary skeletal disorder characterized by multiple enchondromas confined to one side of the body, predominantly affecting the limbs. Unlike Maffucci syndrome, Ollier disease does not involve soft tissue hemangiomas.

 

Option D. Multiple FD: McCune Albright syndrome - McCune-Albright syndrome is characterized by fibrous dysplasia (FD), café-au-lait spots, and endocrine abnormalities. Fibrous dysplasia causes abnormal fibrous growths in place of normal bone, which is not what the radiographs show.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiographs demonstrate multiple enchondromas along with phleboliths in the soft tissues, findings that are indicative of Maffucci syndrome. This syndrome is characterized by the presence of both enchondromas and soft tissue hemangiomas.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 552

choices.text: Bullet shaped metacarpals
Beaking of vertebra

questions.text: In evaluating a patient for congenital hypothyroidism, which of the following findings would not be expected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bullets shaped metacarpals

 

Option A:

 

Bullet-shaped metacarpals are not typically associated with congenital hypothyroidism. They are seen in mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS), a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down glycosaminoglycans.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Wormian bones: Wormian bones are small, extra bone pieces that occur within a suture in the cranium. They are often associated with congenital hypothyroidism and are indicative of delayed closure of the sutures.

 

Option C. Beaking of vertebra: Vertebral beaking refers to the superior and/or inferior protrusions on the vertebral bodies. It can be seen in several conditions, including congenital hypothyroidism, and indicates an abnormality in vertebral development.

 

Option D. Epiphyseal dysgenesis: Epiphyseal dysgenesis, which refers to abnormal development of the epiphyses (ends of long bones), is another radiographic finding associated with congenital hypothyroidism, and it is due to a delay in the ossification process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bullet-shaped metacarpals are not associated with congenital hypothyroidism; rather, they are a characteristic radiographic finding in mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS).

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 880

choices.text: Fracture neck of femur

questions.text: Which condition is associated with a "rotting fence post" appearance of the femur on radiographic imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hyperparathyroidism

 

Option B:

 

Rotting fence post appearance is seen due Rickets + hyperparathyroidism.

 

Hyperparathyroidism can lead to subperiosteal resorption of bone, particularly along the radial aspects of the phalanges and distal clavicles. In cases of severe disease, combined with rickets or osteomalacia, it can lead to metaphyseal changes that resemble a "rotting fence post," especially around the femoral neck.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fibrous Dysplasia: Fibrous dysplasia of the bone causes a replacement of normal medullary bone with fibrous tissue, which can result in a ground-glass appearance on radiographs. It does not typically give a "rotting fence post" appearance.

 

Option C. Paget’s Disease: Paget's disease of bone involves a disordered bone remodeling process, with mixed lytic and sclerotic phases. Characteristic findings include thickened cortical bone with an enlarged, "cotton wool" appearance. It does not cause a "rotting fence post" appearance.

 

Option D. Fracture Neck of Femur: A femoral neck fracture is a break in the proximal aspect of the femur. While it can lead to irregularity of the bone contour, it does not resemble the changes seen in rickets or hyperparathyroidism, and it would not be described as a "rotting fence post" appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "rotting fence post" appearance of the femur, indicating metaphyseal changes resembling rickets combined with cortical erosions, is characteristic of hyperparathyroidism, particularly when concurrent with rickets or osteomalacia.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 598

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with severe back pain that has been gradually worsening over the past few weeks. The patient reports that the pain is worse at night and is not relieved by rest or over-the-counter pain medications. He also reports significant weight loss over the past few months. On physical examination, there is tenderness to palpation over the thoracic and lumbar spine. There is also mild weakness in the lower extremities and a loss of sensation below the level of the umbilicus. The X-ray of the spine is shown here. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vertebral metastasis

 

Option D:

 

The winking owl sign, in which the missing pedicle corresponds to the closed eye, the contralateral pedicle to the other open eye, occurs due to a vertebral bony metastasis causing destruction of the pedicle.

 

Vertebral metastasis The "winking owl" sign noted on spinal X-rays, which suggests the absence or destruction of a pedicle, can be indicative of metastatic disease. In the context of progressive back pain, weight loss, and neurological symptoms, vertebral metastasis is a strong consideration.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pott spine: Pott disease, or spinal tuberculosis, can cause destruction of the vertebral bodies leading to kyphosis and potentially an abscess formation. While it may present with back pain and systemic symptoms, it typically also includes a history of exposure or risk factors for tuberculosis.

 

Option B. Burst fracture: A burst fracture involves the dispersion of bony fragments due to a high-energy axial load injury. It usually presents acutely after trauma and typically doesn't cause progressive symptoms over weeks to months without a history of major trauma.

 

Option C. Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis may lead to compression fractures of the spine, which can cause back pain and height loss. However, the clinical presentation of gradual severe pain, weight loss, and neurological deficits is not typical of primary osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In a patient presenting with severe, progressive back pain, unrelieved by rest, with systemic symptoms such as weight loss, and neurological deficits, along with radiographic evidence of the "winking owl" sign, vertebral metastasis should be highly suspected.

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 594

choices.text: Serum vitamin D levels
Serum alkaline phosphate levels

questions.text: A 70-year-old female is on treatment with Alendronate for 7 years for osteoporosis. Now she complains of pain in right thigh. What is the next investigation to be performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. X-ray

 

Option B:

 

Chronic bisphosphonate use has been associated with atypical femoral fractures (AFF). Plain X-rays revealed a distinct pattern of a transverse or short oblique fracture line, lateral cortical thickening, and medial spiking.

 

An X-ray is the first-line imaging modality for suspected fractures. In patients on long-term bisphosphonate therapy, there's a risk of atypical femoral fractures, which can be identified by specific radiographic features on an X-ray.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. DEXA scan: A DEXA (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) scan measures bone mineral density and is used to diagnose osteoporosis or monitor its treatment. However, it is not used to diagnose acute conditions like a fracture.

 

Option C. Serum vitamin D Levels: Vitamin D levels are important for bone health, and deficiency can cause or exacerbate osteoporosis. However, serum vitamin D would not be the first investigation for acute thigh pain in this context.

 

Option D. Serum alkaline phosphate levels: Alkaline phosphatase can be a marker for bone turnover, but elevated levels are more often associated with conditions like Paget’s disease of bone. It's not specifically useful for diagnosing fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with a history of long-term Alendronate use who presents with thigh pain, an X-ray should be performed to rule out an atypical femoral fracture, a known complication of chronic bisphosphonate therapy.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 594

questions.text: The 3D-CT image of the skull shows multiple Wormian bones, which are additional bone pieces that are found within the cranial sutures. Which of the following conditions is this finding least associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Achondroplasia

 

Option C:

 

Wormian bones is the name given to the additional small bones sometimes found between the cranial sutures of the bones of the skull vault, most commonly in relation to the lambdoid suture. 

 

Achondroplasia is a form of short-limbed dwarfism. The condition is characterized by an abnormality in the conversion of cartilage to bone, especially in the long bones; however, Wormian bones are not a typical feature.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism can be associated with the presence of Wormian bones, especially in congenital hypothyroidism where delayed closure of the cranial sutures can occur.

 

Option B. Osteogenesis Imperfecta: 

Osteogenesis imperfecta, a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones, is commonly associated with Wormian bones due to the defective connective tissue and abnormal ossification.

 

Option D. Down’s syndrome: Down’s syndrome, a chromosomal disorder, is also associated with the presence of Wormian bones, which may be due to the delayed suture closure or other developmental anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wormian bones, extra ossicles at the sutures of the skull, are seen in various conditions but are least associated with achondroplasia, where the primary issue is with long bone growth, not skull suture ossification.

 

Causes of Wormian bones:

 

  • P: pyknodysostosis
  • O: osteogenesis imperfecta
  • R: rickets
  • C: cleidocranial dysostosis
  • H: Hypothyroidism
  • S: syndrome of Downs

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 648

questions.text: A female patient presents with sore throat, difficulty in swallowing and sensation of lump in one side of mouth. The plain X-ray demonstrates the following image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Eagle’s syndrome

 

Option B:

 

Eagle syndrome refers to symptomatic elongation of the styloid process or  calcified stylohyoid ligament  and causes pain in the throat, neck, and face.

 

Eagle’s syndrome is characterized by an elongated styloid process or calcified stylohyoid ligament, which can lead to throat pain, neck pain, facial pain, and dysphagia. This condition can be diagnosed with imaging studies like X-rays or CT scans that show the elongation of the styloid process.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tonsillar Hypertrophy: Tonsillar hypertrophy can lead to discomfort and the sensation of a lump, it would not typically be visualized as a bony structure on an X-ray.

 

Option C. Adenoid Calcification: Adenoid calcification can cause symptoms similar to tonsillar hypertrophy, it is not typically associated with the elongated bony structure indicated on the X-ray.

 

Option D. Cervical Rib: A cervical rib is an extra rib that arises from the seventh cervical vertebra, which can cause thoracic outlet syndrome. It would not usually be associated with throat symptoms and is not what is visualized in the presented X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eagle’s syndrome is diagnosed based on the clinical presentation of throat pain, facial pain, and dysphagia along with the radiographic evidence of an elongated styloid process or calcified stylohyoid ligament, which is consistent with the findings on the patient's X-ray.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition,

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents with chronic low back pain for the past several months. The pain is worse in the morning and improves with activity. He also reports stiffness in his lower back that lasts for several hours and decreased flexibility. He has a family history of inflammatory arthritis. On physical examination, he has limited lumbar spine mobility and tenderness to palpation. Lab tests reveal elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). MRI of the spine and pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ankylosing spondylitis

 

Option A:

 

The above MRI is a coronal STIR sequence of sacro-iliac joint which is shown bone marrow hyperintensity suggestive of edema, and erosions which point to sacroiliitis, a pathognomic feature seen in Ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) AS is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the axial skeleton, causing characteristic sacroiliitis seen on MRI as bone marrow edema and erosions, along with symptoms of back pain and stiffness that improves with exercise. It fits the patient’s clinical and radiological presentation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. DISH: DISH is a non-inflammatory condition characterized by calcification and ossification of the spinal ligaments and entheses. It does not typically present with significant bone marrow edema or the erosive changes seen in sacroiliitis.

 

Option C. Fluorosis: Fluorosis is caused by excessive fluoride intake and affects bones and teeth, leading to sclerosis and calcification of the ligaments, but it does not typically present with the inflammatory back pain or sacroiliitis seen in the MRI.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA): RA is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects peripheral joints and can cause inflammation in the spine. However, the MRI findings of sacroiliitis are more indicative of AS than RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with chronic back pain and stiffness, family history of inflammatory arthritis, elevated inflammatory markers, and MRI findings of sacroiliitis, the most likely diagnosis is ankylosing spondylitis.

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 620

choices.text: Garden spade deformity
Swan neck deformity
Dinner fork deformity

questions.text: The X-ray shows a deformity characterized by the bowing of the radial shaft, increased interosseous space, and dorsal subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint, leading to a volar and ulnar tilted distal radial articular surface, volar translation of the hand and wrist, and a dorsally prominent distal ulna. What is this deformity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Madelung deformity

 

Option C:

 

Madelung deformity refers to the bowing of the radial shaft with increased interosseous space and dorsal subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint results in a volar and ulnar tilted distal radial articular surface, volar translation of the hand and wrist, and a dorsally prominent distal ulna.

 

Madelung deformity involves a triad of changes: bowing of the radius, shortening and dorsally prominent distal ulna, and a triangular configuration of the carpus. It often presents during adolescence, particularly in females, and can be bilateral.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Garden Spade Deformity: The term "garden spade deformity" is not commonly used in orthopedic or radiographic terminology and may not describe a specific condition.

 

Option B. Swan Neck Deformity: Swan neck deformity is characterized by hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint of the fingers, commonly seen in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis. It is not related to the findings in the provided X-ray.

 

Option D. Dinner Fork Deformity: Dinner fork deformity typically refers to the appearance of a forearm after a displaced Colles' fracture, where the distal fragment of the radius is dorsally displaced and angulated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiographic appearance of bowing of the radial shaft with dorsal subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint and the corresponding clinical findings are indicative of Madelung deformity. This condition often presents in adolescent females with bilateral involvement, pain, limited range of motion, and noticeable deformity of the wrist.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 518

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with a history of progressive pain and stiffness in his right arm and hand for several years. On physical examination, he has thickening of the bones of his right arm and hand, with palpable bony ridges and irregularities. The affected limb also appears larger than the contralateral side. X-rays is shown below. There is no history of trauma or infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Melorheostosis

 

Option C:

 

The patient presents with progressive pain and stiffness in the right arm and hand, and has thickening of the bones with palpable bony ridges and irregularities, as well as enlargement of the affected limb. X-rays show linear hyperostosis with a "dripping candle wax" appearance, which is characteristic of Melorheostosis.

 

Melorheostosis is characterized by a "dripping candle wax" appearance on X-rays due to cortical hyperostosis. It often affects a single limb and presents with the pain, stiffness, and bony thickening noted in the patient’s description, aligning with the findings on the X-ray.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteopetrosis: Osteopetrosis is a group of disorders characterized by increased bone density due to defective osteoclast resorption. The bones appear uniformly sclerotic, and the condition is typically bilateral and symmetrical, which is not consistent with the patient's unilateral presentation and the X-ray findings.

 

Option B. Fluorosis: Fluorosis results from chronic fluoride poisoning, leading to sclerosis of bones and calcification of ligaments. The skeletal changes are usually generalized and diffuse, rather than the linear pattern seen on the X-ray.

 

Option D. Paget's Disease: Paget's disease of bone involves abnormal bone remodeling with mixed osteolytic and osteosclerotic phases. It can present with bone pain, enlargement, and deformity. However, the "dripping candle wax" appearance on X-ray is not typical of Paget’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presentation of progressive pain and stiffness in a limb, with palpable bony irregularities and an X-ray showing linear hyperostosis with a "dripping candle wax" pattern, is indicative of Melorheostosis. This rare condition often affects only one limb and leads to progressive sclerosis of cortical bone.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 657

choices.text: Hurler syndrome
Marfan syndrome
Achondroplasia

questions.text: A 2-year-old male is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of short stature. The parents are of average height and deny any family history of dwarfism. On physical examination, the child has a large head with a prominent forehead, short arms and legs, and a broad, flattened nasal bridge. His fingers are short and stubby, and he has a prominent belly. X-rays is shown here. . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Achondroplasia

 

Option C:

 

The patient presents with short stature, a large head with a prominent forehead, short arms and legs, and a broad, flattened nasal bridge. The stubby fingers and prominent belly are also characteristic of achondroplasia.

 

Achondroplasia is a common cause of disproportionate dwarfism characterized by rhizomelic shortening of limbs, macrocephaly with frontal bossing, and midface hypoplasia, which aligns with the patient's clinical presentation. The "champagne glass pelvis" seen in the X-ray is a classic sign associated with this condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hurler Syndrome: Hurler syndrome is a mucopolysaccharidosis characterized by developmental delay, corneal clouding, and organomegaly. Skeletal abnormalities include dysostosis multiplex, which differs from the findings in this X-ray.

 

Option B. Marfan Syndrome: Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder presenting with tall stature, arachnodactyly, ectopia lentis, and cardiovascular abnormalities, which does not correlate with the clinical features or X-ray findings of this patient.

 

Option D. Turner Syndrome: Turner syndrome affects females and presents with short stature, shield chest, and gonadal dysgenesis. This syndrome does not typically present with the skeletal findings observed in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of short stature, macrocephaly with frontal bossing, rhizomelic limb shortening, and the characteristic "champagne glass pelvis" on X-ray is diagnostic of Achondroplasia, which is a genetic disorder resulting in the most common form of disproportionate short stature.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 648

choices.text: Osteogenesis imperfecta
Rickets
Achondroplasia

questions.text: A 9-month-old male is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of poor growth and developmental delay. The parents report that the child has been exclusively breastfed. On physical examination, the child is small for his age. There is also a prominent anterior fontanelle on the child's skull. Laboratory tests reveal low serum calcium and phosphate levels, as well as elevated alkaline phosphatase. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rickets

 

Option B:

 

The patient presents with poor growth and developmental delay, as well as a prominent anterior fontanelle, which are all characteristic of rickets. The low serum calcium and phosphate levels, as well as elevated alkaline phosphatase, are consistent with a diagnosis of rickets.

 

The X-ray shows widening of the growth plates, with metaphyseal fraying or cupping, and overall decreased bone density. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones and frequent fractures, but is unlikely to present with the Xray changes seen in this case.

 

Option C. Achondroplasia is characterized by short stature and limb abnormalities, but does not typically present with the skull abnormalities seen in this case.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatasia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by defective bone mineralization and low alkaline phosphatase levels, but typically presents with more severe symptoms than those seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of developmental delay, poor growth, a prominent anterior fontanelle, laboratory findings of hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia with elevated alkaline phosphatase, and radiographic signs of metaphyseal fraying and cupping are indicative of Rickets, typically caused by vitamin D deficiency in children.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 596

choices.text: Marfan syndrome
Osteogenesis imperfecta

questions.text: A 6-year-old male is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of frequent fractures. The parents report that the child has had multiple fractures since infancy, often with minimal trauma. On physical examination, the child has a short stature and a triangular face with a small chin. The sclera of the eyes appears blue, and the teeth appear yellow and discolored. X-rays of the long bones reveal multiple fractures and evidence of previous fractures. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteogenesis Imperfecta

 

Option C:

 

The patient presents with frequent fractures since infancy, a short stature, and a triangular face with a small chin, which are all characteristic of osteogenesis imperfecta. The blue sclera of the eyes and yellow, discolored teeth are also typical findings in this condition. X-rays reveal multiple fractures and evidence of previous fractures, which is also consistent with a diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta.

 

Osteogenesis Imperfecta This genetic disorder causes brittle bones that fracture easily, blue sclerae due to a collagen defect, and dental imperfections known as dentinogenesis imperfecta, fitting the patient's clinical and radiographic presentation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Non-accidental Injury: While multiple fractures could suggest non-accidental injury, the systemic features such as blue sclerae, dental issues, and the triangular face point away from this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Marfan Syndrome:  Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder characterized by tall stature, arachnodactyly, and cardiovascular abnormalities, which does not match this patient's presentation.

 

Option D. Rickets: Rickets is a disorder of bone mineralization that can lead to deformities and fractures, but does not explain the blue sclerae or dental abnormalities seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The constellation of symptoms including frequent fractures with minimal trauma, blue sclerae, dental discoloration, short stature, and a triangular face, along with radiographic evidence of multiple fractures, is characteristic of b, a genetic disorder affecting collagen production and bone strength.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 602

choices.text: Perform a CT scan
Perform an MRI

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl had an accident while riding her bicycle, resulting in weakness in her hands and legs without any pain. Although cervical spine x-ray revealed no fractures or misalignment, she was unable to stand up. What should be the next course of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Perform an MRI

 

Option D:

 

Based on the clinical presentation, the patient may have a Spinal Cord Injury with No Radiographic Abnormality (SCIWORA), which occurs when there is no visible injury on X-ray or CT scan, but the patient exhibits objective myelopathy.

 

Perform an MRI an MRI is sensitive for detecting soft tissue injuries, including spinal cord injuries, even in the absence of bone injury. Given the patient's neurological symptoms despite normal X-ray findings, an MRI is warranted to rule out spinal cord injury.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Perform a CT Scan: A CT scan is useful for evaluating bony structures and can detect fractures not visible on X-ray. However, it may not detect all spinal cord injuries, particularly those without bone injury.

 

Option B. Provide Reassurance: While reassurance is an important aspect of patient care, it is not appropriate to offer reassurance without further investigation when neurological symptoms are present.

 

Option C. Begin Physiotherapy: Initiating physiotherapy without identifying the underlying cause of neurological symptoms could potentially worsen the condition if there is an undiagnosed spinal cord injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of traumatic injury with neurological deficits but normal X-ray findings, an MRI should be performed to evaluate for possible s(SCIWORA) or other soft tissue injuries that may not be visible on X-ray or CT scan.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 503, 544

choices.text: Osteosarcoma
Ewing sarcoma
Chondrosarcoma

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presents with a 4-week history of worsening left leg pain. The pain is constant, dull, and aching in nature. The patient denies any trauma or injury to the leg. On examination, there is tenderness over calf with swelling. There is no warmth or erythema. X-ray is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ewing sarcoma

 

Option B:

 

The patient's symptoms and imaging findings which show a permeative lytic lesion with lamellated periosteal reaction known as onion-peel reaction are consistent with Ewing sarcoma, malignant bone tumor that typically presents in first two decades.

 

Ewing sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that typically presents in children and young adults. It can cause permeative lytic lesions and an onion-skin periosteal reaction, as observed in the X-ray.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that often presents with a mixed lytic and sclerotic pattern and may exhibit a sunburst periosteal reaction. It commonly affects the metaphysis of long bones.

 

Option C. Chondrosarcoma: Chondrosarcoma is a cancer of cartilage cells, usually occurring in adults. It often shows a stippled or popcorn-like calcification on imaging.

 

Option D. Fibrosarcoma:  Fibrosarcoma is a malignant tumor of fibroblasts and presents with a lytic pattern on imaging but lacks the characteristic periosteal reaction seen in Ewing sarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When evaluating a young patient with constant bone pain and characteristic radiographic findings of a permeative lytic lesion with a layered periosteal reaction, Ewing sarcoma should be highly suspected. This condition requires prompt evaluation and referral to oncology for further management, including biopsy and staging.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 588

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a 2-month history of left hip pain that is exacerbated by weight-bearing activities. He denies any history of trauma, infection, or steroid use. On examination, there is tenderness over the left hip joint with limited range of motion. What is the best imaging modality to diagnose the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. MRI

 

Option A:

 

MRI Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for early detection of avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head. It can identify bone marrow edema, which is an early sign of AVN, even before changes become visible on X-rays or CT scans.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. CT Scan: A CT scan can provide detailed images of bone and can detect subchondral fractures and changes in bone structure. However, it is less sensitive than MRI for early detection of AVN because it may not capture the earliest changes in bone marrow.

 

Option C. Bone Scan: Bone scans involve the use of radioactive material to evaluate bone metabolism. They are sensitive for detecting bone changes but lack specificity. They might be positive in AVN but can also be positive in many other bone pathologies; hence, they are not as diagnostic as MRI.

 

Option D. PET Scan: Positron Emission Tomography (PET) scans are typically used to detect cancer, assess cancer response to treatment, and evaluate brain function. They are not the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing AVN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with hip pain and clinical suspicion of AVN, MRI is the best initial imaging study due to its high sensitivity and specificity for detecting early marrow changes, which precede the development of subchondral fractures and collapse.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 526

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of increasing headaches and hearing loss. He reports no history of trauma or infection and denies any recent changes in medication. On examination, there is tenderness over the frontal and parietal bones with palpable bony deformities. Serum alkaline phosphatase levels are elevated. X-ray of the skull is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Paget’s disease

 

Option A:

 

The radiograph shows cotton wool skull which is diagnostic of Paget's disease.

 

During the early stage of this disease, radiological features include osteolytic (lucent) regions, which are later followed by coarse trabeculae and bony enlargement. Sclerotic changes manifest themselves much later in the disease process. The following lesions have been observed:

 

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesion
  • Cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull
  • Diploic widening: both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved, with the former usually more extensively affected
  • Tam o' Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Multiple myeloma shows lytic bone lesions, punched out lesions – characteristically seen as Raindrop skull.

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism shows salt and pepper skull

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis is an infection usually involving the skull base – temporal, sphenoid or occipital bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paget's disease of bone can be diagnosed through the identification of characteristic radiographic findings such as the "cotton wool" appearance on skull X-rays, coupled with clinical features including increasing headaches, hearing loss, and elevated serum alkaline phosphatase levels.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 782
